title: OpenAI Launches Codex: An Autonomous Programming Agent

rawLines.text: Huge news. OpenAI is launching a new
coding agent. It's called Codeex. Codex
is a web-based software engineering
agent that's designed to work pretty
much autonomously, so you can have it
working on many different features and
bugs in parallel while you watch. I've
been using Codeex for a couple days, and
it's pretty great. So, I invited
Alexander Ambiraos, a member of the
product staff at OpenAI who's
responsible for Codeex, to come on the
show and talk to us about it. We're
going to demo Codeex together and talk
through all of the product decisions
that led to its release. We walk through
Codex screen by screen and he'll talk to
us about how OpenAI is thinking about
agents and what OpenAI's vision is for
the future of programming. Let's jump
in.
[Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
Alexander, welcome to the show. Hey,
thanks for having me. So for people who
don't know, you are a member of the
product team at OpenAI and you are one
of the people responsible for building
Codeex, which is a new programming agent
that is launching today. Well, we're
recording technically recording
yesterday, but it's launching today,
Friday. I'm super excited about it. I
got to try it. Um I have a review coming
out along with this podcast and uh I
just wanted to go through it with you
and understand like all the things that
you put into it and all the ways that
you're thinking about it. So thank you
for coming on the show. Yeah, excited to
be here and uh thank you for being an
early tester. Awesome. So, what I want
to do is um just like give people right
off the bat a sense for like actually
what it looks like and and like we can
sort of talk about it together. So, uh
so this is codeex terminate processes.
Great. This is codeex and it's a coding
agent, right? So, uh I can type in a
task like uh please replace the headline
on the homepage with codeex is out now.
Uh, and I can just press code. And one
of the really cool things is um it
doesn't go into like an agent
experience. Like it just adds it as a
task. So it's like you're it's basically
like built to make me just create a
bunch of tasks and then not look at them
more or less is what that's how I feel
about it. So tell tell me about like
this screen and how you thought about
this and and why you did it like this.
Yeah. So I'm so excited that you're
screen sharing this uh and showing
people so we get to nerd out about all
the details. Um, but you know, for
anyone listening, basically Codex is
it's a cloud-based software engineer
that can work on like many tasks in
parallel. And um, you know, there's a
ton of AI tools out there. I feel like
programming with AI is completely
different now than it was like 2 years
ago. And this form factor that we're
looking at is kind of the beginning of
us thinking about what is it going to
look like even like a year from now
today. Um, and the big shift is, you
know, today when people are accelerated,
um, working with AI, uh, a lot of it is
like very like a very tight feedback
loop. It's like very collaborative, like
a lot of like really good tab
completion, right? And like really good
chat. Um, and sort of where we see
things going is um, we have these really
awesome reasoning models and we want to
give them time to think and we want to
let them use tools safely so they can do
more stuff. for example, like running
commands to execute tests to be more
sure of their changes um and then
iterate. And so we basically want to
give the agent its own computer to do
work in. And so as we started thinking
about that um you know, you kind of
realize, okay, this this feels a bit
like delegation. Um and I'm sure we'll
get into this, but we tried a bunch of
different form factors for what it would
feel like to delegate to an agent,
including like maybe the most obvious
one, which is just like talking to chat
GPT and having it do stuff. Um but the
short version of it is what we realized
is that engineers wanted like this
really functional tool to be like very
efficient in how they delegate. Um and
so the thing you see here it's like you
know it's very structured. You've got
the list of tasks that you have. You can
see how many lines were changed in each.
You can see what the status of the PR is
which is ultimately the thing you're
going for. Um, and so this ended up just
being a thing that we iterated our way
too. Um, that we thought was the best
first version to ship, but actually
like, you know, I would love it if we
end up talking a bit about what it might
look like in chat as well because we we
definitely plan to bring it there. I
would love to do that and and I have a
bunch of follow-ups on that specific
point about like sort of the chat GBT
versus what what this is point. But um,
so to give people like a sense um, for
how this actually looks. So uh, a couple
I did a couple things yesterday. I
actually like shipped a feature on one
of our products that I've never I've
never coded in. Um like I've never
touched that repo and I shipped a
feature to prod uh yesterday with Kieran
is the Kieran is the um GM of that
product and he's a really really
talented engineer who's also early an
early tester of of codec. So he was
watching me the whole time to make sure
I didn't mess anything up. But it was
really cool. Um, and basically like to
show people what it looks like. Um,
uh, we have this, uh, we have this UI
in, um, this is not the right one.
Uh, weird. You're looking for the diff,
right? Yeah. Where is it? Um, you should
be able to click. Um, there you go.
Yeah. Nice. By the way, this UI that
Dan's showing us has been like editing
like changing massively like every
single day as we race towards launch.
So, you know, thanks again for testing
our league. Yeah, this this may not be
what you actually see or depending on
when you're listening to this, it
definitely is not going to be what you
see. But, uh, for now, for people who
are listening, basically, I clicked into
one of the tasks and you can see
basically for the feature I wanted to
build, we have this we have a um a view
that I wanted to create a a persisted
collapsed state. we wanted to be able to
like collapse that particular view and I
just said I just said do that basically.
Um and you can kind of see a uh log of
all the things it thought while it was
doing the um doing the task and then it
gives me like a summary of um what it
did. I can see a diff um and I can also
just push that right to GitHub. And one
of the things that um that I noticed is
the the summary is very concise. And in
talking to Kieran about the code that it
generates, um the code seems very um
minimal or like tur. Uh can you tell me
a little bit about how you thought about
making this thing code and and talk
about its um talk about what it makes?
Yeah. Um it's a great question. So, uh
Codeex the agent runs on a custom model
that we train just for this product
called Codex 1. Um, Codex 1 is a version
of 03 that's optimized for real world
software engineering, but not only not
only optimized for real world software
engineering, but also optimized for this
form factor, which is, hey, it's going
to go off and do a bunch of work and
then you're going to get a diff back.
And, you know, once you're using this a
lot, actually, you're going to be
getting many diffs a day back. And uh
you know I'm sure this thing we talk
about a lot with even human software
engineers like would you rather review
like 1000 line diffs or 20 50 line diffs
or you know 1,000line PR right
definitely the thing is you don't want
to review the 10,000 line PR right um
and so and was as we trained this model
we we both wanted to make sure it was
great at coding so the model like
slightly over outperforms 03 actually on
like eval like swbench but more
importantly actually we wanted it to
produce like code that was really
mergeable and then talk about the work
that it in a way that was like actually
really reviewable for the human
reviewer. So, um we put a lot of effort
into style here. Um you know, making
sure it's not doing things like adding
extraneous comments, making sure that uh
the style that it's using is actually
like the style in your codebase and not
like its own style that it has and
thinks is correct. Um okay. And so
getting to your point about the the PR
descriptions, um you know, early
versions we've had of tools like this or
models that did this would tell you
everything about what they did. Um, and
you know, just actually to give you a
bit of the story, like in our UI, we
would like show you kind of the model's
thoughts first and then we would show
the diff underneath. And whenever like a
full-time software engineer was trying
to use this a lot, they were always
like, "Man, I just want to see the diff.
Like, I don't want to read the
description until I see the diff. And if
the diff is good, then maybe I'll look
at the description." Um, and so we kind
of ended up realizing like, hey, there's
actually like kind of a spec for what a
good PR description looks like. Uh, and
that's like pretty concise and only
maybe explaining like at a high level
what it is, the non-obvious parts. Like
you definitely don't want to duplicate
content that's in the diff. Um, then the
other thing we realized is that because
it didn't run on your computer, you you
didn't necessarily see each iterative
step. And so you really want to know how
validated is this change and how did the
model try to validate the change. And so
you can see here on the left side, the
model's also describing the testing that
it ran. Um, and here, uh, we put a lot
of effort into, first of all, just
making sure that it's like never
hallucinating, but also making sure that
it tells you when tests passed and when
tests failed, which like super important
in a concise way. And then lastly,
perhaps the thing I'm most excited
about, like if you mouse over that
little like terminal icon next to the
testing. Uh, yeah. So, it's sort of like
the last thing on the third line there.
It's a little icon. It's like a carrot.
Yeah. So, we'll actually pro the model
learns how to site its output. And so
it's not just saying like, hey, here's a
test I ran. Um, you know, in the case of
test that passed, which it didn't hear,
you know, it's not saying like, hey, the
test passed. Uh, believe me, it's
saying, hey, the test passed. Here's
like a deterministic citation that we
did to actually pull the part from like
the log out so you can review it
yourself and be super sure. Uh, and in
this case, the test it tried to run
failed. And it's kind of telling you
this because maybe you would want to run
it yourself or like upgrade the
environment it's operating in to so that
those tests can be run. Um, and it's
giving you the output there so you can
like go and review it and improve it.
That's really interesting. This this
particular repo. So I actually this uh
the one we're looking at I I I kicked
off uh the the collapse state task in
the wrong repo at first. So this is the
wrong repo. This is an internal um this
is an internal app we built and so it
does not have any tests. Um, and I was
just kind of curious what it would do uh
if if I gave it a task that was totally
not not possible to accomplish and it
found a section something else to
collapse. Um, so that's kind of just
like an interesting little detail, but
yeah. Okay, that makes a lot of sense.
One of the things that I notice about um
this that feels different from like a
Devon for example is I don't see this.
It has an environment that it uses that
it sets everything up and it runs a test
and all that kind of stuff, but it
doesn't have a browser for example. So
it's not going and like logging in to
the app to check if it's working or not.
Like tell me about that decision. Why'
you do it that way? Yeah, I would say
that's more of a just like sequencing
decision rather than like um a vision
decision. Like ultimately kind of like
the thing that we view ourselves as
building like super long-term is just
like one super assistant. Um, and it has
a bunch of tools and you don't even have
to decide, you know, if you even want to
use code mode or if you want to use
like, I don't know, newsletter publisher
mode. You just have one assistant catch
PT and you can just ask it for stuff and
it'll use the appropriate tools and
it'll also just like answer quickly if
that's the right thing or it'll like do
work if that's the right thing. So long
term that's that's where we're trying to
get to just like one thing with all the
tools. Um, but what we're starting with
is kind of like, hey, we want to ship a
research preview. We want to like
iteratively deploy this out in like
small steps as capabilities grow and
we're going to start like the smallest
most constrained thing possible. So for
instance, uh it doesn't take multimodal
inputs yet. We'd obviously love to add
that. Uh it doesn't have a browser that
would obviously be useful for validating
front end changes. Um it doesn't even
have network access. So the way that it
runs uh is so when when you kick off a
task um we set up a container pull the
repo into that container um and then
with network access we run some setup
commands that like you wrote so it's not
the agent running those commands it's
like you writing those commands and so
that can pull in like you know any
dependencies like npmi npm install or
you know whatever you need and then
actually we cut off internet access and
I think we updated the logs recently to
show that so if you were to like click
into logs and scroll to the top you
would see like no internet access all
the way at the
Uh, and then you would see no internet
access. Um, yeah. So, like we ran the
environment setup that you put in there
and then we turned off internet and then
the agent runs. And that's just for
absolute maximum safety. Um, you know, I
haven't actually ever seen it happen,
but you know, there's like a theoretical
risk or a tail risk that there could be
like some exfiltration. Maybe the agent
wants to go to Stack Overflow and ask a
question about some code and it pastes
it in. Right? That's a theoretical
scenario. Um, and so we're starting
really small in scope and then over time
we'll start like adding more and more
capabilities. Got it. And that actually
brings me to my next thing which is
which is one of my gripes about this. um
which is it's not it like the fact that
it's not in chatbt means that it feels

very like it's definitely for senior

it's it's really interesting like
delegating to agents requires like a

actually I think will take time for

use out of
and we'll like I think end up

stuff um but you know people are pretty

with tools locally on their computer
right now and in fact we have the codec

you can do a back and forth CLI have it
exe some commands it'll ask you for

computer, but you can kind of sit with

shift mindset shift that we've seen

delegate to. Um, I'll just share for
because it's you know kind of
interesting here. One of them is like an

we've seen a lot of people who are using

many many tasks without thinking
actually too hard about whether it's
going to work or you know whether uh
it's like perfectly described or not and
whenever you need to do something new
you just kind of fire off a new task.
And so for example a really common use
case is like on call triage. It's like
maybe you don't know if uh what the the
bug is. you you know you were talking
about how like oh like I've noticed it
works best if I can kind of see through
the full arc of the feature like you
don't need to know that you just fire it
and then sometimes it's like hey here's
like the exact fix and you're just like
wow like amazing not only did I save

faster than I could have ever gotten to
it otherwise other times maybe it just
like provides a draft and then you have
to land it in your own time and and
other times it like just maybe finds
where the bug is or helps you just
reason about it and so it's kind of like
this idea of like this is a service to
that accelerates me the developer and
I'm going to use it without necessarily
always knowing if it's going to like
provide emergible PR or not. Um so
that's like on call triage as an
example. Another like very analogous
place we see people use it is like um in

like think about what they want to do

Fire off some stuff, then get to their

like those two examples I gave you. So I

it's to build something pretty general.
And, um, a lot of specialization, at

just kind of be general for you, right?
And
so kind of the where I see things like
